frameDefinitions: This frame contains words that necessarily indicate the motion of two distinct objects.
This frame concerns the movement of a Theme and an Agent and/or Carrier.
Some Stimulus causes a Cognizer to think of a prior Phenomenon due to its perceived similarity.
An Agent intends and takes steps towards bringing about a State_of_affairs or, metonymically, towards acquiring a Sought_entity .

A Manner describes general or specific characteristics of an event in one of three ways:  First, it can refer to how a Comparison_event transpires, absent the influence of an entity (e.g. 'the way you talk').
The words in this frame describe situations in which a Perpetrator forcibly seizes control over a Victim's Vehicle to gain some end.  ''
frameExamples: She <t>accompanied</t> him in the ambulance to Hollywood Memorial Hospital.
Karl <t>carried</t> the books across campus to the library on his head.
I burned down the malt shop where we used to go just because it <t>reminds</t> me of you
He completed the task in a fervent <t>manner</t>.
French farmers have <t>hijacked</t> a lorry and destroyed its load of strawberries.
listRoleDefinitions: This is the entity, frequently a living being, which moves in relation to the <fen>Cotheme</fen>. Normally the <fen>Theme</fen> frame element is expressed as an external argument.
This frame element is the second moving object, expressed as a direct object or an oblique:

<fen>Source</fen> marks any expression which implies a definite starting-point of the motion of the <fen>Cotheme</fen>. In prepositional phrases, the  object expresses the starting point of motion. With particles, the starting point of motion is understood from context.

<fen>Path</fen> marks phrases that describe the <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen>'s trajectory of motion and which are neither expressions of the  <fen>Source</fen> nor the <fen>Goal</fen> of motion. The notion <fen>Path</fen> also includes directional expressions.

Any expression which tells where the <fen>Cotheme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion expresses the frame element <fen>Goal</fen>. Note that if the <fen>Cotheme</fen> is animate, the <fen>Theme</fen> need not also end up in the same place. Some particles imply the existence of a <fen>Goal</fen> which is understood in the context of utterance.

<fen>Area</fen> marks expressions which describe a general area in which the motion of <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen> takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular and not to consist of a single linear path. Locative setting adjuncts of motion expressions may also be assigned this frame element.
Phrases that denote a physical path on which the motion of <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen> takes place are marked <fen>Road</fen>.
The direction in which the <fen>Theme</fen> and <fen>Cotheme</fen> move.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the motion occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the location which provides a setting for a defined motion (that is one with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen> or <fen>Goal</fen>).
The <fen>Agent</fen> is a sentient being who physically controls the movement of the <fen>Theme</fen> via the carrier, accompanying the <fen>Theme</fen>.
<fen>Goal</fen> identifies the endpoint of the path.
<fen>Source</fen> indicates the beginning of the path along which the <fen>Theme</fen> travels.
Path along which carrying occurs.
The objects being carried.
<fen>Area</fen> is used for descriprion of a general area in which the carrying action takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular or not to consist of a single, linear path.
The <fen>Carrier</fen> provides support for the <fen>Theme</fen>.  Movement of the <fen>Carrier</fen> results in movement of the <fen>Theme</fen>.
The time in which the carrying event takes place.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the general area that serves as a setting for the specific motion of the <fen>Agent</fen> and <fen>Theme</fen> (with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, or <fen>Goal</fen>).
The <fen>Cognizer</fen> is the person who remembers the <fen>Phenomenon</fen> .
The <fen>Phenomenon</fen> is the mental content that a <fen>Cognizer</fen> remembers.
The entity or situation that causes the <fen>Cognizer</fen> to think of the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the Cognizer remembers the <fen>Phenomenon</fen>.
The <fen>Agent</fen> makes an attempt to achieve a <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> or to  obtain a <fen>Sought_entity</fen>.
The entity that the <fen>Agent</fen> attempts to acquire.
A state or event that the <fen>Agent</fen> wants to bring about. The Agent may but need not be a participant in that <fen>State_of_affairs</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> when the attempt occurs.
The place where the <fen>Agent</fen> is seeking to achieve a particular <fen>State_of_affairs</fen> or to acquire a <fen>Sought_entity</fen>.

The <fen>Comparison_event</fen> is the principal event being characteriszed by the <fen>Manner</fen>. The <fen>Manner</fen> of this <fen>Comparison_event</fen> is often used in comparison with the <fen>Foreground_event</fen>.
The <fen>Salient_entity</fen> that is associated with or directly responsible for the <fen>Comparison_activity</fen>.
The description of the <fen>Comparison_event</fen> or <fen>Comparison_activity</fen>.
A description of the <fen>Manner</fen>.
The <fen>Salient_entity</fen> conducts or engages in the <fen>Comparison_activity</fen> that is being described.
This is the person (or other agent) who forcibly seizes control over a vehicle to gain some end.
This is the means of transportation which gets under the control of the perpetrator. Example: The terrorists hijacked <fex name='Vehicle'>the plane</fex>.
This role describes the people that are suffering as a result of the <fen>Perpetrator</fen>'s action.
When the event occurs.
Where the event takes place.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Pat</fex> accompanied me for five miles in a blue Toyota.
Pat accompanied <fex>me</fex> down the street.
The cat chased the mouse <fex>out of the house</fex>.
The bikers followed the truck <fex>west</fex>.
The children chased the ball <fex>into the park</fex>. (The children end up in the park.)
The police followed the suspects <fex>all around town</fex>.
The police followed the suspect <fex>on the interstate</fex> for several miles.
The tracking dogs chased their target <fex>towards the river</fex>, where they lost it.
<fex>Karl</fex> carried the books across the campus to the library.
Karl carried the books <fex>to the library</fex>.
Karl hauled the books <fex>from the library</fex>  to the office.
Karl carried the books <fex>across the campus</fex>.
Karl toted <fex>the books</fex> to the car.
<fex>The boat</fex> ferried the troops across the river.
<fex>Even in such a small port</fex>, these boats would transport many tons of trade-goods in to shore annually.
You remind me <fex>of my uncle Jerry</fex>
<fex>Internationalization</fex> conjures up a world of diplomatic exchanges and international agencies in which the interests of ex-colonial and great powers still linger

<fex>Those states</fex> sought a remedy that would substantially change the company's business
practices.
Or the monstrous Saddam, who filled mass graves to bursting, invaded two neighboring countries, and avidly sought <fex>weapons of mass destruction</fex>.
His enemies sought <fex>his destruction</fex>.
The disclosure came as prosecutors successfully sought <fex>in federal court</fex> to keep Luise Garofalo behind bars.
The rebels skyjacked a plane <fex>with 89 passangers</fex>.
